issues.description: The problem statement consistently refers to a static method named calculateTotalPrice(Meal): int (UML and textual description), but both the template and the solution use the name computeMealCost(Meal) instead. This naming mismatch is a structural inconsistency in the method signature students are expected to provide: they will be told to implement/call calculateTotalPrice, while the provided Main (template) and the solution use computeMealCost. This can confuse students about the exact method name to implement and call, and may cause automated tests or starter code (Main) to fail if names differ.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the method name consistent across all artifacts. Either (A) rename computeMealCost(Meal) in the template and solution to calculateTotalPrice(Meal) (keeping the same static int signature), or (B) update the problem statement and UML to refer to computeMealCost(Meal) instead of calculateTotalPrice. Ensure the chosen name is used in Main, the SealSaloon class, and the documentation so students implement and call the same method.

issues.description: The problem statement's UML and requirements name the static method as calculateTotalPrice(Meal) while both the template's example usage (Main.java) and the solution implementation use the name computeMealCost(Meal). This mismatch means students reading the problem will look for calculateTotalPrice, but the starter code/samples and reference solution use computeMealCost, creating unnecessary confusion when mapping the requirement to the code to implement or call.
issues.suggested_fix: Use a single, consistent name for this method across all artifacts. Either (A) rename the implementation and template calls from computeMealCost to calculateTotalPrice, or (B) update the problem statement/UML to refer to computeMealCost. Prefer renaming the code to calculateTotalPrice to match the problem text (or update the UML if computeMealCost is the intended canonical name) so students can directly map the requirement to the provided code.
